Description: The bud stage marks the beginning of pomegranate development. Small, tightly closed buds appear on healthy branches, indicating the onset of flowering.
Causes: Natural developmental phase under favorable temperature, water, and light conditions.
Symptoms: Appearance of small buds with a greenish or reddish tint on branches.
Treatment: No treatment required. Ensure consistent watering and nutrient supply.
MANAGEMENT_TIPS: Monitor soil moisture, provide balanced fertilizer, and protect from aphids or thrips.
Prevention: Regular pruning and maintaining plant hygiene ensure healthy bud formation.
Spread_and_Impact: Healthy stage essential for good flowering and fruit set.

Description: During this stage, buds bloom into flowers that are orange-red in color. Proper pollination determines future fruit yield.
Causes: Result of healthy bud development and balanced nutrient supply.
Symptoms: Bright orange-red flowers appearing on branches, sometimes with minor petal drop.
Treatment: No disease treatment required; maintain pest control and irrigation balance.
MANAGEMENT_TIPS: Encourage pollinators like bees, avoid overwatering, and use micronutrient sprays if needed.
Prevention: Prevent flower drop by avoiding drought stress and nutrient imbalance.
Spread_and_Impact: Vital stage for determining fruit set percentage and yield quality.

Description: Pollinated flowers develop into small green fruits. Proper watering and nutrients are crucial for healthy fruit growth.
Causes: Successful pollination and cell division phase of the fruit.
Symptoms: Formation of small green immature fruits after petal fall.
Treatment: Maintain potassium and calcium levels for fruit set and firmness.
MANAGEMENT_TIPS: Protect from fruit borers and sun scorch. Maintain uniform moisture.
Prevention: Use mulch and regular monitoring to prevent early fruit drop.
Spread_and_Impact: Determines the initial fruit count; sensitive to water and nutrient stress.

Description: Fruits enlarge, and the peel begins to harden. Proper nutrient supply ensures good fruit size and internal quality.
Causes: Natural progression after fruit set with adequate photosynthesis and nutrient supply.
Symptoms: Medium-sized fruits with green to light red peel color.
Treatment: Apply foliar sprays of micronutrients like Zn and Fe if leaves yellow.
MANAGEMENT_TIPS: Irrigate regularly, manage weeds, and protect from fungal infections.
Prevention: Avoid high humidity and water stagnation to reduce fungal risk.
Spread_and_Impact: Ensures fruit enlargement and internal aril development.

Description: Fruits reach full size and color. Arils turn juicy and sweet, indicating harvest readiness.
Causes: Proper nutrient and water management during earlier stages.
Symptoms: Full-sized fruits with glossy red rind and developed arils.
Treatment: No treatment required; focus on pest protection and harvesting at correct time.
MANAGEMENT_TIPS: Avoid water stress near harvest, and handle fruits carefully to prevent cracking.
Prevention: Apply calcium sprays to reduce cracking and maintain uniform ripening.
Spread_and_Impact: Final yield and quality determined; improper care can cause cracking or fungal infection.

Description: A healthy pomegranate plant exhibits glossy green leaves, firm stems, and well-developed fruits without any spots or cracks.
Causes: Proper irrigation, nutrients, and absence of pathogens or pests.
Symptoms: No visible disease symptoms; normal fruit color and leaf texture.
Treatment: No treatment needed; continue balanced care and pest observation.
MANAGEMENT_TIPS: Maintain field hygiene and avoid excess moisture.
Prevention: Use disease-free seedlings and regular preventive sprays.
Spread_and_Impact: No disease spread or yield loss.

Description: A severe bacterial disease caused by *Xanthomonas axonopodis* pv. *punicae* leading to dark spots on leaves, stems, and fruits.
Causes: High humidity, rain splashes, and infected plant residues.
Symptoms: Water-soaked lesions on leaves and fruits that later turn dark brown or black.
Treatment: Spray copper oxychloride or streptocycline solution alternately at 15-day intervals.
MANAGEMENT_TIPS: Remove infected plant parts and avoid overhead irrigation.
Prevention: Use disease-free planting material and practice crop rotation.
Spread_and_Impact: Rapid spread during monsoon; can cause severe yield loss.

Description: A fungal disease caused by *Colletotrichum gloeosporioides* resulting in dark, sunken lesions on fruits and leaves.
Causes: Warm and humid conditions favor fungal growth.
Symptoms: Circular brown to black spots with pink spore masses on fruits and leaves.
Treatment: Apply fungicides such as carbendazim or mancozeb every 10–12 days.
MANAGEMENT_TIPS: Ensure good air circulation and remove fallen debris.
Prevention: Avoid excess humidity and wet foliage for long periods.
Spread_and_Impact: Spreads via rain splash; reduces fruit quality and market value.

Description: A foliar fungal disease caused by *Cercospora punicae* characterized by small, circular spots on leaves.
Causes: High humidity and poor air circulation.
Symptoms: Tiny brown to grey circular spots with yellow halos on leaves.
Treatment: Spray with chlorothalonil or propiconazole to control infection.
MANAGEMENT_TIPS: Prune dense canopy and avoid waterlogging.
Prevention: Apply preventive fungicides during monsoon season.
Spread_and_Impact: Can lead to premature leaf fall and reduced photosynthesis.

Description: A fungal infection by *Alternaria alternata* causing black lesions on the rind and sometimes internal rot.
Causes: Wet and humid conditions; entry through cracks or wounds.
Symptoms: Black, concentric ring-like lesions on fruit surface.
Treatment: Spray mancozeb or azoxystrobin alternately every 10–15 days.
MANAGEMENT_TIPS: Avoid fruit injury during handling and control humidity.
Prevention: Harvest fruits at the right maturity to prevent cracking.

Description: Calypso mangoes are known for their vibrant red–yellow skin, small seed, and firm, fibre-free flesh. The fruits are uniform in shape, making them ideal for commercial packing and fresh market sales.
Characteristics: Smooth skin, oval shape, firm texture, medium size, and a sweet refreshing flavour.
Growing_Conditions: Thrives in warm tropical climates with well-drained soil and sufficient sunlight.
Appearance: Bright red blush over golden-yellow skin, firm and fibreless flesh with pleasant aroma.
Taste_Profile: Sweet, mildly tangy, and crisp with a juicy texture.
Usage: Commonly consumed fresh, used in salads, desserts, and processed mango products.
Post_Harvest_Notes: Fruits maintain firmness and have good shelf life, making them suitable for export.
Quality_Indicators: Uniform color, smooth skin, firm feel, and absence of blemishes.

Description: Kesar mango, often called the 'Queen of Mangoes', is known for its rich saffron-colored pulp, sweet aroma, and smooth, juicy texture. It is widely grown in Gujarat and is highly valued for its flavor.
Characteristics: Oval shape, smooth skin with greenish-yellow to golden-orange hue, strong aroma, and vibrant saffron-colored flesh.
Growing_Conditions: Thrives in warm climates with moderate humidity, well-drained soil, and good sunlight exposure.
Appearance: Medium-sized fruits with a uniform yellow-orange skin tone. Flesh is fiberless, soft, and intensely colored.
Taste_Profile: Exceptionally sweet with a rich, creamy texture and deep aromatic flavor.
Usage: Ideal for fresh consumption, desserts, milkshakes, pulp extraction, and traditional sweets like aamras.
Post_Harvest_Notes: Has moderate shelf life; requires careful handling to prevent bruising and maintain quality.
Quality_Indicators: Uniform yellow color, smooth skin, strong aroma, and soft but firm feel when ripe.
